description.narrative: Insatsen fokuserar på mödra- och barn hälsovård.
The contribution is focusing on mother- and child care.

Marie Stopes International Afghanistan (MSIA) has raised awareness of sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR) and increased access to high quality sexual and reproductive health (SRH) information, education, services and products for hundreds of thousands of women and girls in Afghanistan.
The overall goal of the project is to contribute to the reduction of maternal and child mortality and to the realisation of the SRHR of women and girls by achieving significant reductions in unwanted pregnancies among the most vulnerable.
The specific goal of the project will be to increase the mCPR (modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate) by increasing access to high-quality SRH information and services to the most vulnerable (including adolescents, the poorest and survivors of SGBV) in seven provinces of Afghanistan.
The specific objective will be achieved through three interlinked outcomes:
1. Improve community awareness and acceptance of SRH services and increase demand (from women and couples) for SRH services.
2. Increase access of quality SRH services across 7 provinces and 25 districts in Afghanistan.
3. Improve access to psychosocial counselling services for survivors of violence and remove policy barriers to enable women and girls to exercise their SRHR.
Within the framework of the intervention a special effort is planned to be made to reach marginalized women and adolescent girls, including survivors of SGBV and human rights violations, as well as imprisoned women and girls.
During the current phase of the programme MSIA launched a contact centre dedicated to psychosocial counselling for survivors of gender based violence (SGBV). During the planned phase MSIA will expand the services to all the static clinics. The planned phase will also include advocacy to improve the conditions for women in prison, and to monitor their human rights, including general health care services.
The intervention will also continue supporting MSIAs capacity and systems development on a cross cutting level to ensure programme performance with maximum results.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
Results in 2021: Marie Stopes International Afghanistan (MSIA) is delivering sexual and reproductive health and family planning services in eight provinces (Herat, Jawzjan, Balkh, Kandahar, Kabul, Helmand, Kunduz, and Nangarhar) through the Sida funded project.
In these eight provinces, seven centres, five mobile health teams, 250 community health workers and 13 MS Ladies (trained mid-wives who provide individual care at women's and girl's homes) are providing quality services to women and girls in Afghanistan. Using these various delivery channels, the project aims to expand community understanding and acceptance as well as access to SRH services among women and couples. It is MSI assessment that hundreds of thousands of women and girls in Afghanistan have had access to high-quality SRHR information, education, and services as a result of the Sida funded project.
Through the Sida funded project, MSIA has delivered a total of 190,301 family plannig (FP) services (including 66,024 condoms) and 1,310 post-abortion care (PAC) services from Jan to November 2021.These services are provided to a total of 45,810 clients, in which 43% are youth between the 14-24 age categories.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
